22.q: What did Balak do when he and Balaam arrived at Kiriath Huzoth?

22.a: Balaam could see only a part of the Israelites in their camp.
22.q: What could Balaam see when Balak took him up to the shrines of Baal?

23.a: Balaam told Balak to build seven altars for him and prepare seven bulls and seven rams.
23.q: What did Balaam the prophet tell Balak the king to do?

23.a: Balak did as Balaam requested, and they offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
23.q: What did Balak do about Balaam's request?

23.a: Balaam told Balak that Yahweh might come to meet him and then he would tell Balak whatever Yahweh showed him.
23.q: What did Balaam tell Balak that Yahweh might do when Balaam went aside?

23.a: Yahweh told Balaam to return to Balak to speak a message to him.
23.q: What did Yahweh tell Balaam to do?

23.a: Balaam asked, "How can I curse those whom God has not cursed? How can I oppose those whom Yahweh does not oppose?"
23.q: What two questions did Balaam ask in the first part of the message God gave him?

23.a: Balaam said that the Israel did not consider themselves to be just an ordinary nation.
23.q: What did Balaam say about how Israel considered themselves?

23.a: He said no one could number even one fourth of Israel.
23.q: What did Balaam say about the size of Israel?

23.a: Balaam wished to die the death of a righteous person, and that he wanted his life's end to be like Israel's end.
23.q: What kind of death did Balaam wish to die?

23.a: Balak said that Balaam had blessed his enemies instead of cursing them.
23.q: What did Balak say that Balaam had done instead of cursing his enemies?

23.a: Balaam answered that he was careful to say only what Yahweh put in his mouth.
23.q: How did Balaam reply when Balak said he had blessed his enemies instead of cursing them?

23.a: Balak wanted Balaam to curse Balak's enemies.
23.q: What did Balak want Balaam to do when Balak took Balaam to another place where he could see the nearest part of Israel, Balak's enemies?

23.a: Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Pisgah and he built seven more altars there and offered up a bull and a ram on each altar.
23.q: Where did Balak take Balaam, and what did he do there?

23.a: Balaam said that he was going to meet with Yahweh.
23.q: What did Balaam tell Balak he was going to do while Balak stood by his burnt offering?

23.a: Balaam said that God does not lie and he does not change his mind.
23.q: What was the message that Yahweh put in Balaam's mouth?

23.a: Balaam said that he could not reverse God's command to bless Israel.
23.q: What did Balaam say that he could not do about God's command to bless Israel?

23.a: Balaam said that Yahweh was with the Israelites.
23.q: Who did Balaam say was with the Israelites?

23.a: He said God's strength is like the strength of a wild ox.
23.q: What did Balaam say God's strength is like?

23.a: Sorcery and fortune telling could not work against nor harm Israel.
23.q: What things could not work against nor harm Israel?

23.a: It had to be said, "Look what God has done!"
23.q: What had to be said about Jacob and Israel?

23.a: The people of Israel were like lions that attackrd and ate their victims.
23.q: How did Balaam describe what the people of Israel were like?

23.a: Balak said to Balaam that he should neither curse nor bless the Israelites at all.
23.q: What did Balak say to Balaam after Balaam gave his prophecy?

23.a: Balaam told Balak that he could say only what Yahweh told him to say.
23.q: What did Balaam tell Balak was the only thing that he could say?

23.a: Balak thought God might allow Balaam to curse the Israelites from another place.
23.q: What did Balak think Balaam might be able to do if he took Balaam to another place?

23.a: Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Peor.
23.q: So now where did Balak take Balaam?

23.a: Balaam told Balak to build seven altars so Balak did as Balaam said and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
23.q: What did Balaam tell Balak to do this time and what did Balak do?

24.a: Balaam did not use sorcery but looked toward the wilderness.
24.q: What did Balaam the prophet not do when he saw that blessing Israel pleased Yahweh?

24.a: When Balaam raised his eyes and saw Israel camped, the Spirit of God came on Balaam and he received a prophecy.
24.q: What happened when Balaam raised his eyes and saw Israel camped, each in their own tribe?

24.a: Balaam bowed down with his eyes open.
24.q: What did Balaam do when he saw a vision from the Almighty?

24.a: Balaam said that the tents of Jacob were beautiful.
24.q: What did Balaam say about Jacob's tents?

24.a: Balaam described valleys like gardens by the riverside, like aloes planted by Yahweh, and like cedars beside the waters.
24.q: How did Balaam describe the beauty of the place where Israel lived?

24.a: God blessed Israel with flowing water that would also water the seeds they planted.
24.q: With what did God bless Israel in the land in which they lived?

24.a: Their kingdom would be honored.
24.q: What would happen to the kingdom of Israel?

24.a: God brought his people out of Egypt.
24.q: From what place did God bring his people?

24.a: Balaam said the Israel's strength was like a wild ox.
24.q: What did Balaam say about the strength of Israel?

24.a: Balaam said Israel would eat up the nations who fought against him, break their bones to pieces, and shoot them with his arrows
24.q: What would happen to the nations who fought against Israel?

24.a: Those who blessed Israel would be blessed and those who cursed Israel would be cursed.
24.q: What did Balaam prophesy would happen to those who blessed or cursed Israel?

24.a: Balak struck his hands together in anger.
24.q: How did Balak show his anger against Balaam?

24.a: Balak said that Yahweh kept Balaam from getting his reward.
24.q: Who did Balak say kept Balaam from getting the promised reward?

24.a: Balaam told Balak that he could not go beyond Yahweh's word to say anything bad or good, or to say anything that he might want to say.
24.q: What did Balaam tell Balak he could not do even if Balak gave him his palace full of silver and gold?

24.a: Balaam said that he could only say what Yahweh told him to say.
24.q: What did Balaam say was the only thing that he could say?

24.a: Balaam warned Balak what Israel was going to do to Balak's people in the days that were coming.
24.q: About what did Balaam warn Balak before he returned to his own people?

24.a: Balaam said that his prophecy, words, knowledge, and visions came from God, the Most High, the Almighty.
24.q: From whom did Balaam say that his prophecy, words, knowledge, and visions came?

24.a: Balaam said that a star would come out of Jacob, and a scepter would rise out of Israel.
24.q: What did Balaam say would come out of Jacob and rise out of Israel?

24.a: Balaam said that that star and scepter would shatter and destroy Moab's leaders and all the descendants of Seth.
24.q: What did Balaam say that star and scepter would do to Moab's leaders and all the descendants of Seth?

24.a: Edom and Seir would become possessions of Israel, and Israel would conquer them with force.
24.q: What would happen to Edom and Seir when Israel conquered them with force?

24.a: A king who would have dominion would come out of Jacob and he would destroy the survivors of their city.
24.q: What would come out of Jacob and what would he do?

24.a: The final end of Amalek, the greatest of nations, would be destruction.
24.q: What would happen to Amalek, the greatest of nations?

24.a: Kain would be ruined when Assyria carried them away captive.
24.q: What did Balaam prophesy would happen to Kain and the Kenites who lived in a strong place in the rocks?

24.a: Ships would come from the coast Kittim which would attack Assyria and conquer Eber; but they, too, would end in destruction.
24.q: What would come from the coast of Kittim which would attack Assyria and conquer Eber, and then what would happen to them?

24.a: Balaam got up and returned to his home. Balak also went away.
24.q: When Balaam ended his final prophecy, what did he do and what did Balak do?

25.a: The men began to sleep with the women of Moab and people ate and bowed down to the Moabite gods.
25.q: What caused Yahweh's anger to be kindled against Israel?

25.a: Yahweh told Moses to kill all the Israelite leaders who had joined in worshiping Baal of Peor and to hang those leaders up before Yahweh.
25.q: What did Yahweh tell Moses to do to Israel's leaders who worshiped Baal of Peor?

25.a: When one of the men brought a Midianite woman among his family, the people of Israel were weeping at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
25.q: Where was the community of the people of Israel when one of the men brought a Midianite woman among his family?

25.a: When Phinehas saw the Israelite man and the Midianite woman, he rose up from among the community and took a spear in his hand.
25.q: What did Phinehas, son of Eleazar do when he saw the Israelite man and the Midianite woman?

25.a: Phineas the priest took a spear and thrust a spear into the bodies of both the man and the woman.
25.q: What happened to the Israelite who brought a Midianite woman into the camp in the sight of Moses?

25.a: God sent a plague so that those who died were 24,000 in number.
25.q: What did God do to stop them from sleeping with the Moabite women and worshiping Baal of Peor, and how many died ?

25.a: Yahweh's rage was turned away because Phinehas was passionate with Yahweh's zeal.
25.q: Why was Yahweh's rage turned away from the people of Israel?

25.a: Yahweh called his covenant of everlasting priesthood, his covenant of peace.
25.q: What was the first name Yahweh called his a covenant of everlasting priesthood?

25.a: Yahweh made a covenant with Phinehas because he was zealous for Yahweh and had atoned for the people of Israel.
25.q: Why did Yahweh make a covenant of everlasting priesthood with Phinehas?

25.a: God told Moses to treat the Midianites as enemies and attack them because they had treated Israel like enemies with their deceitfulness.
25.q: Why did Yahweh tell Moses to treat the Midianites as enemies and attack them?

25.a: He referred to Cozbi, the daughter of a leader in Midian who was killed on the day of the plague, as their sister.
25.q: How did Yahweh refer to Cozbi, the daughter of a leader in Midian who was killed on the day of the plague?

26.a: Yahweh told them to count all the people of Israel from twenty years old and up, by their tribes, who were able to go to war.
26.q: What did Yahweh tell Moses and Eleazar to do after the plague?

26.a: They told the people they needed to count the people from 20 years old and up, who had come out of the land of Egypt.
26.q: What did Moses and Eleazar tell the people Yahweh had commanded them to do?

26.a: The firstborn of Israel was Reuben.
26.q: Who was the firstborn of Israel?

26.a: The clans of Reuben's descendants numbered 43,730 men.
26.q: How many men did the clans of Reuben's descendants number?

26.a: Eliab's sons were Nemuel, Dathan and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram rebelled against Yahweh by following Korah who had challenged Moses and Aaron.
26.q: Who were the sons of Eliab, descendant of Reuben, and what did his sons do?

26.a: The earth swallowed them up and fire devoured 250 men.
26.q: What happened to all the followers of Korah that became a warning sign?

26.a: Korah's line did not die out.
26.q: Whose line did not die out?

26.a: The clans of Simon was the next of Israel's sons; they numbered 22,200 total men.
26.q: Who was listed next of Israel's sons, and how many did their descendants number?

26.a: The male descendants of gad numbered 40,500 men.
26.q: How many did the male descendants of Gad number?

26.a: They died in the land of Canaan.
26.q: What happened to Judah's sons, Er and Onan?

26.a: The other descendants of Judah numbered 76,500 men.
26.q: How many men were in the other descendants of Judah?

26.a: The number of the men of the clans from Issachar's descendants was 64,300 men.
26.q: What was the number of the men of the clans from Issachar's descendants?

26.a: The number of the men from Zebulun's descendants were 60,500 men.
26.q: What was the number of the men from Zebulun's descendants?

26.a: The children of Joseph were Manasseh and Ephraim.
26.q: Who were Joseph's children?

26.a: Zelophehad son of Hepher had no sons and had five daughters.
26.q: How many daughters did Zelophehad son of Hepher have although he had no sons?

26.a: The men that came from the descendants of Manasseh numbered 52,700 men.
26.q: How many men came from the descendants of Manasseh?

26.a: The men that came from the descendants of Ephraim numbered 32,500 men.
26.q: How many men came from the descendants of Ephraim?

26.a: The men that came from the descendants of Benjamin numbered 45,600 men.
26.q: How many men came from the descendants of Benjamin?

26.a: The men that came from the descendants of Dan were numbered 64,400 men.
26.q: How many men came from the descendants of Dan?

26.a: The men that came from the descendants of Asher numbered 53,400 men.
26.q: How many men came from the descendants of Asher?

26.a: The men that came from the descendants of Naphtali were numbered 45,400 men.
26.q: How many men were numbered from the descendants of Naphtali?

26.a: The complete count of men from among the people of Israel was 601,730.
26.q: What was the complete count of the men of the people of Israel?

26.a: Yahweh said to divide the land among those men as an inheritance according to the number of their names.
26.q: How did Yahweh say the land would be divided?

26.a: The clans who were larger in number would be given more inheritance and the clans who were smaller in number would be given less inheritance.
26.q: Who would get more and who would get less land for their inheritance?

26.a: The land would be divided by random lots from among their ancestor's tribes.
26.q: What way would be used to divide the land?

26.a: Gershon, Kohath, and Marari were from the Levite clans.
26.q: From what clan were Gershon, Kohath, and Marari?

26.a: The Libnites, Hebronites, Mahlites, Mushites, and Korahites were descended from Levi.
26.q: From what clan did the Libnites, Hebronites, Mahlites, Mushites, and Korahites descend?

26.a: Amram's ancestor was Kohath.
26.q: Who was Amran's ancestor?

26.a: Their children were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam, their sister.
26.q: Who were the children of Amram and Jochebed, a descendant of Levi who was born in Egypt?

26.a: Aaron was the father of Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
26.q: Who was the father of Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar?

26.a: Nadab and Abihu died when they offered unacceptable fire before Yahweh.
26.q: What happened to Nadab and Abihu and why did they die?

26.a: The number of males from Levi who were one month old and older was 23,000.
26.q: What was the number of males from Levi that were one month old and older?

26.a: The males one month old and up were not counted among Israel's descendants because they had no land inheritance among the people of Israel.
26.q: Why was the number of males one month old and up not counted among Israel's descendants?

26.a: Moses and Eleazar counted the people of Israel in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho.
26.q: Where did Moses and Eleazar the priest count the people of Israel?

26.a: There was no man counted that had been counted by Moses and Aaron when the descendants of Israel had been counted in the wilderness of Sinai.
26.q: How many men were found who had been counted by Moses and Aaron the priest when the descendants of Israel had been counted in the wilderness of Sinai?

26.a: Yahweh had said that those people would die in the wilderness, except for Caleb and Joshua.
26.q: Why wasn't Moses and Aaron able to count these descendants?

27.a: Zelophehad died in the wilderness not because he was one of those who gathered against Yahweh in the company of Korah, but he died because of his own sin.
27.q: Why did Zelophehad die in the wilderness?

27.a: The daughters of Zelophehad wanted Moses to give them land among their father's relatives.
27.q: What did the daughters of Zelophehad want Moses to give them?

27.a: When a man died without a son, then his inheritance must pass to his daughter.
27.q: What did Yahweh say should happen to the inheritance of a man when he dies and has no son?

27.a: If a man had no son or daughters, his inheritance passed to his brothers.
27.q: If a man died and has no son or daughter, who received his inheritance next?

27.a: Moses was to be gathered with his people because he and Aaron rebelled against the command of Yahweh by striking the rock in anger.
27.q: Why was Moses to be gathered with his people instead of going into the land which Yahweh had given them?

27.a: Moses asked that Yahweh appoint a man over the community so they would not be like sheep that have no shepherd.
27.q: Why did Moses ask Yahweh to appoint a man over the community?

27.a: Yahweh instructed Moses to choose Joshua because he was a man in whom Yahweh's spirit lived.
27.q: Why did Yahweh instruct Moses to lay his hand on Joshua, son of Nun?

27.a: Moses was to give Joshua the authority to seek Yahweh's will by the decisions of the Urim and command all Israel to obey him.
27.q: How much authority did Yahweh command Moses to give to Joshua?

27.a: Moses placed Joshua before Eleazar the priest and all the community and laid his hands on him as he commanded him to lead as Yahweh had instructed him.
27.q: How did Moses respond to Yahweh's command?

28.a: Yahweh said the sacrifices produced a sweet aroma for him.
28.q: What did Yahweh say the sacrifices produced for him?

28.a: The sacrifices in the regular burnt offerings in the mornings and in the evenings were to be male lambs without blemish.
28.q: What two animals, one in the morning and one in the evening, were to be offered in the regular burnt offerings each day?

28.a: They had to offer a tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a grain offering mixed with a fourth of a hin of beaten oil.
28.q: What else did they have to offer with the regular burnt offering?

28.a: One fourth of a hin of strong drink had to be added to these sacrifices and poured out in the holy place.
28.q: What was the drink offering to Yahweh that had to be added to those regular burnt offerings and what did they do with it?

28.a: On the Sabbath day, two male lambs, each a year old without blemish and fine flour mixed with oil, and a drink offering had to be offered.
28.q: What had to be offered on the Sabbath day?

28.a: At the beginning of the month the animals of the special sacrifices were two young bulls, one ram, and seven one year old male lambs without blemish.
28.q: What special animal sacrifices had to be made at the beginning of each month?

28.a: The grain offerings for each of the two bulls was three tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil, and the grain offering for one ram was two tenths of fine flour mixed with oil.
28.q: What were the grain offerings given with the two bulls and for the one ram?

28.a: Each lamb had a grain offering of a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil.
28.q: What was the grain offering for each lamb?

28.a: These special burnt offerings were to be given every month throughout the year.
28.q: How often were these special burnt offerings to be given?

28.a: One male goat was offered as a sin offering to Yahweh.
28.q: What was offered with the regular burnt offering and the drink offering?

28.a: Yahweh's Passover came during the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month.
The feast was to be held on the fifteenth day of the first month, and they ate bread without yeast for seven days.
28.q: On what day was the feast to be held and what kind of bread was eaten for seven days?

28.a: They had a holy assembly to honor Yahweh; on that day they did no normal work.
28.q: What did they do to honor Yahweh on the first day of the Passover, and what did they not do that day?

28.a: They offered two young bulls, one ram, and seven one year old male lambs without blemish.
28.q: What animal sacrifices had to be made during the seven days of the Passover?

28.a: With the bulls they offered three tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil and with the ram they offered two tenths.
28.q: What grain offerings did they give with the two young bulls and with the ram?

28.a: With each lamb they offered a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil.
28.q: What did they offer with the lambs?

28.a: The male goat was given as a sin offering to make atonement for themselves.
28.q: Why was the male goat given?

28.a: On the seventh day of the feast of the Passover they had to have a holy assembly to honor Yahweh and do no normal work on that day.
28.q: What happened on the seventh day of the feast of the Passover?

28.a: On the day of the first fruits, they offered a new grain offering to Yahweh in their Festival of Weeks, and had a holy assembly to honor Yahweh and did no normal work on that day.
28.q: What did they have to offer of the day of the first fruits in their Festival of Weeks and what did they do on that day?

29.a: On the first day of the seventh month the people of Israel had a holy assembly to honor Yahweh; they did no normal work and they blew trumpets.
29.q: Why did the people of Israel have a holy assembly on the first day of the seventh month; what did they not do and what did they do on that day?

29.a: On that day, they offered a burnt offering of one young bull, one ram, and seven male lambs a year old—each without blemish—to produce a sweet aroma for Yahweh.
29.q: On that day, what animals did they offer and why did they offer it?

29.a: With the animals they offered a grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil.
29.q: What was the grain offering that they offered with the animals?

29.a: They offered one male goat as a sin offering to make atonement for themselves.
29.q: Why did they offer one male goat?

29.a: They were to make this sin offering in the seventh month, in addition to all of the usual offerings they were to make each month.
29.q: When were they to make this sin offering, in addition to all of the usual offerings they were to make each month?

29.a: On the tenth day of the seventh month the people of Israel had to have a holy assembly to honor Yahweh, humble themselves, and do no work.
29.q: What did Yahweh say the people of Israel had do on the tenth day of the seventh month?

29.a: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month the people of Israel had to offer offer one young bull, one ram, and seven male lambs a year old—without any blemish.
29.q: What animals did they have to offer as a burnt offering to produce a sweet aroma for Yahweh on the fifteenth day of the seventh month?

29.a: The people of Israel had to put flour mixed with oil with each of the animals.
29.q: What did the people of Israel have to put with each of the animals?

29.a: The male goat was given as a sin offering.
29.q: Why was the male goat given?

29.a: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month there was another holy assembly to honor Yahweh in which they did no normal work and kept the festival for him seven days.
29.q: On what day was there another holy assembly to honor Yahweh in which they did no normal work and this time kept the festival for him for seven days?

29.a: On this day they offered thirteen young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs a year old, each without blemish.
29.q: On this day how many bulls, rams and male lambs a year old without any blemishes did they offer?

29.a: In addition to the grain offerings, drink offerings, and other animal sacrifices, a male goat was offered as a sin offering.
29.q: In addition to the grain offerings, drink offerings, and other animal sacrifices, what other animal was offered as a sin offering?

29.a: On the second day of the assembly, they offered twelve young bulls.
29.q: How many bulls did they offer on the second day of the assembly?

29.a: On the third day of the assembly they offered eleven bulls, and all the sacrifices of the previous day.
29.q: How many bulls did they offer on the third day of the assembly?

29.a: On the fourth day of the assembly the people of Israel had to offer ten bulls as well as all the sacrifices of the previous day.
29.q: How many bulls did they offer on the fourth day of the assembly in addition to all the sacrifices of the previous day?

29.a: On the fifth day of the assembly the people of Israel had offer nine bulls and all the sacrifices of the previous day.
29.q: How did the people of the Israel have to celebrate the fifth day of the assembly?

29.a: On the sixth day of the assembly the people of Israel had to offer eight bulls and all the sacrifices of the previous day.
29.q: How did the people of Israel celebrate the sixth day of the assembly?

29.a: On the seventh day of the assembly the people of Israel were to offer seven bulls and all the sacrifices of the previous day.
29.q: How were the people of Israel to celebrate the seventh day of the assembly?

29.a: On the eighth day of the assembly the people of Israel were to have another solemn assembly and do no normal work.
29.q: How were the people of Israel to celebrate the eighth day of the assembly?

29.a: They had to offer one bull, one ram, and seven male lambs a year old, each without blemish.
29.q: What animals were they to offer on the eighth day for their burnt offering by fire to produce a sweet aroma for Yahweh?

29.a: In addition to the bull, ram, and seven male lambs which were a year old and without blemish, they were to offer grain offerings and drink offerings as well as one male goat as a sin offering.
29.q: What else did they have to offer in addition to the bull, ram, and seven male lambs a year old and without blemish? [29:35]

29.a: Besides their burnt offerings, grain offerings, drink offerings, and fellowship offerings, they had vows and freewill offerings.
29.q: Besides their burnt offerings, grain offerings, drink offerings, and fellowship offerings, what other offerings did they have?

29.a: Moses told the people of Israel everything that Yahweh had commanded him to say.
29.q: What did Moses tell the people of Israel?

30.a: He must not break his word.
30.q: What must a person who makes a vow not do?
If a young woman who lives in her father's house makes a vow to Yahweh and her father hears her vow but says nothing to reverse the vow, is the vow in force?

30.a: No, the vow is not in force.
30.q: If a young woman who lives in her father's house makes a vow to Yahweh and her father stops her on the day that he hears of it, is the vow in force?

30.a: Yes, the vows are in force.
30.q: If a young woman who is married makes her vows and her husband hears about it and does nothing to stop her, are the vows in force?

30.a: No, the vows are not in force.
30.q: If a young woman's husband stops her on the day that he hears about her vows, are the vows in force?

30.a: Yes, the vow is in force.
30.q: If a widow or a divorced woman makes a vow to Yahweh, is the vow in force?

30.a: Yes, her vows must remain in force.
30.q: If a woman in her husband's family makes a vow and her husband hears of it and says nothing to her, is the vow in force?

30.a: No, her vow will not remain in force.
30.q: If a woman in her husband's family makes a vow and her husband cancels it on the day that he hears about it, is the vow in force?

30.a: Yes, it will be in force, and if he breaks it, he will be responsible for her sin and suffer the penalty for breaking it.
30.q: If a wife's husband tries to cancel her vow a long time after he has heard about it, is the vow in force?

31.a: Yahweh told Moses that Moses would die and be gathered to his people.
31.q: What did Yahweh tell Moses would happen after he avenged the people of Israel against the Midianites?

31.a: Each tribe was to send a thousand soldiers.
31.q: How many soldiers was each tribe to send to war against Midian?

31.a: Every Midianite was killed, including their kings and Balaam.
31.q: What happened in Israel's battle against Midian?

31.a: The army of Israel took the women of Midian, their children, and all their cattle, flocks, and goods as plunder.
31.q: What did the army of Israel take as plunder from Midian?

31.a: Moses was angry with the officers because they let had all the women of Midian live.
31.q: Why was Moses angry with the officers of the army of Israel?

31.a: Moses was angry because the women of Midian had caused the people of Israel, through Balaam's advice, to commit sin against Yahweh.
31.q: Why was Moses angry that the officers of the army of Israel had let the women of Midian live?

31.a: Moses told the officers to kill every male among the little ones and every woman who had slept with a man.
31.q: Who did Moses command the officers of the army of Israel to kill?

31.a: Moses told the officers of the army they could take for themselves all the young girls who had never slept with a man.
31.q: Who did Moses tell the officers of the army they could take for themselves?

31.a: All the men in the army who had killed anyone or touched a dead person had to purify themselves.
31.q: Which men in the army of Israel had to purify themselves?

31.a: They were to stay outside the camp for seven days.
31.q: How long did the soldiers who had killed anyone or touched a dead body have to camp outside the camp of Israel?

31.a: Those camped outside the camp of Israel had to purify themselves on the third and and seventh days.
31.q: On which days were those soldiers and their prisoners camped outside the camp of Israel supposed to purify themselves?

31.a: Moses asked Eleazar to divide the plunder from the war between the soldiers who went out to battle and all the rest of the community.
31.q: Between what two groups did Moses ask Eleazar the priest to divide the plunder from the war?

31.a: The soldiers were to pay a tax of one out of every five hundred persons, cattle, donkeys, sheep, or goats.
31.q: What was the tax that the soldiers were to pay to Eleazar the priest?

31.a: The people of Israel were to pay a tax of one out of every fifty persons,cattle, donkeys, sheep, and goats.
31.q: What was the tax the people of Israel were to give to the Levites who took care of the tabernacle?

31.a: They brought the offerings to make atonement for themselves before Yahweh.
31.q: Why did the officers of the army of Israel bring Yahweh offerings?

31.a: It was placed in the tent of meeting to remind Yahweh of the people of Israel.
31.q: Why was all the gold from the commanders of thousands and from the captains of hundreds given over to Yahweh?

32.a: The descendants of Reuben and Gad went and spoke to Moses because they saw that the land of Jazer and Gilead was a wonderful place for livestock and the descendants of Reuben and Gad had large numbers of livestock.
32.q: Why did the descendants of Reuben and Gad go and speak to Moses?

32.a: He thought they wanted to settle there and let their brothers go to war.
32.q: Why did Moses think the descendants of Gad and Reuben wanted to stay in Jazer and Gilead?

32.a: He thought the hearts of the people would become discouraged.
32.q: What did Moses think would happen to the hearts of the people of Israel if the people of Gad and Reuben settled there?

32.a: They had seen the land and then discouraged the hearts of the people of Israel so they refused to enter the land.
32.q: What had their fathers done when Moses sent them from Kadesh Barnea to examine the land?

32.a: Yahweh took this oath because he was angry that the men of Israel had not completely followed him.
32.q: Why did Yahweh take an oath that none of the men of Israel from twenty years old and up except Caleb and Joshua would see the land which he had sworn to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob?

32.a: He made them wander around in the wilderness for forty years.
32.q: What did Yahweh do because he was angry with the men of Israel?

32.a: They promised to be armed to go with Israel's army and not return until they had led Israel into their place.
32.q: What promise did the descendants of Reuben and Gad make to Moses if he would allow them to build fences for their cattle and cities for their families?

32.a: He told them that if they would go to war with the men of Israel and drive out the enemies in the land, then they could return to the land they possessed and be guiltless towards Yahweh and Israel.
32.q: What did Moses decide to do about the request the descendants of Reuben and Gad had made?

32.a: If they did not cross over and fight with the men of Israel, then they would not receive the land in Gilead, but would acquire their possessions in the land of Canaan.
32.q: What would happen if the descendants of Reuben and Gad did not cross over and fight with the men of Israel to take the land Yahweh had given to them?

32.a: They promised to cross over into the land of Canaan.
32.q: What did the descendants of Reuben and Gad and the half tribe of Manasseh promise to the leaders of the people of Israel?

32.a: He gave them the land of Sihon, king of the Amorites, and of Og, king of Bashan.
32.q: Whose land did Moses give to the descendants of Gad and Reuben, and also to the half tribe of Manasseh?

33.a: They were able to leave openly because the Egyptians were busy burying all their firstborn.
33.q: Why were the people of Israel able to openly leave Rameses without opposition from the Egyptians?

33.a: They choose to camp there because twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees were there.
33.q: Why did the people of Israel choose to camp at Elim?

33.a: There was no water found at Rephidim.
33.q: What could the people of Israel not find at Rephidim?

33.a: Aaron died forty years after the people of Israel had come out of Egypt.
33.q: How long after Israel had come out of Egypt did Aaron die at Mount Hor?

33.a: Yahweh commanded them to drive out all of the land's inhabitants and destroy all their cast figures and shrines.
33.q: What did Yahweh command the people through Moses to do after they crossed over the Jordan into Canaan?

33.a: Yahweh wanted the people of Israel to divide up the land by lot, giving a larger share of land to the large clans and a small share of land to the small clans.
33.q: How did Yahweh want the people of Israel to divide up the land that they were to possess?

33.a: The people whom they allowed to stay would make life difficult for them.
33.q: What would happen if the people of Israel did not drive out the land's inhabitants?

34.a: The nine and one half tribes of Israel would receive the land of Canaan as their possession.
34.q: Who were the people who would receive the land of Canaan as their possession?

34.a: The descendants of Reuben and Gad and the half tribe of Manasseh would receive their share of land beyond the Jordan at Jericho eastward.
34.q: What would the descendants of Reuben and Gad and the half tribe of Manasseh receive as their share of the land?

34.a: The men would be Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and one leader from every tribe.
34.q: Who were the men who would divide the land for their inheritance?

34.a: He commanded them to divide the land of Canaan and to give each tribe of Israel its share.
34.q: What did Yahweh command these men to do?

35.a: He commanded them to give to the Levites some of their own shares of land, cities to live in, and pastureland surrounding the cities.
35.q: What did Yahweh command each one of the tribes of Israel to do for the Levites?

35.a: Forty-eight cities were to be given to the Levites.
35.q: How many cities were to be given to the Levites?

35.a: They were to serve as cities of refuge to which accused murderers could flee.
35.q: What was the purpose for six of the cities that the Levites would receive?

35.a: Anyone who killed someone unintentionally could flee to them and know they would not be killed without standing on trial before the community.
35.q: How would the cities of refuge protect an accused man from his avenger?

35.a: He would be put to death if he struck his victim with an instrument of iron, a stone in his hand, or a wooden weapon and then his victim died.
35.q: What would cause an accused man to certainly be put to death?

35.a: If an accused man without a weapon manhandles anyone or throws something at him while hiding, or strikes him down with his hand so that the victim dies, then the accused man must be put to death.
35.q: What would happen if an accused man without a weapon injured someone so that they die?

35.a: The community must rescue the accused man by returning him to the city of refuge to which he had originally fled.
35.q: What must the community do to rescue from the blood avenger an accused man, whose victim dies through unintentional harm?

35.a: If the blood avenger would find the accused man outside the border of the city of refuge to which he fled, then he could kill him and not be found guilty of murder.
35.q: When could a blood avenger kill the accused man and yet not be guilty of murder?

35.a: He would be free to return after the death of the high priest.
35.q: When would an accused man be free to return to his own property?

35.a: The testimony of more than one witness is needed before a murderer can be put to death.
35.q: What is needed before a murderer can be put to death?

35.a: The people are to accept no ransom for the life of a murderer or for one who has fled to a city of refuge.
35.q: What ransom can people accept for the life of a murderer?

35.a: Only the blood of the one who has shed the blood will atone for the land.
35.q: What is the only thing that can atone for land on which blood has been shed?

36.a: Yahweh had commanded Moses to give Zelophehad's land to his daughters.
36.q: To whom had Yahweh commanded Moses to give the land of Zelophehad?

36.a: If they did that, then their share of land would belong to the tribe into which they married.
36.q: What would happen to Zelophehad's land if his daughters married men from other tribes in Israel?

36.a: When the jubilee came, the share that had belonged to the daughter would belong to her husband's tribe and be taken away from Zelophehad's tribe.
36.q: What would happen to the land that had belonged to a daughter who had married a man from another tribe when the jubilee came?

36.a: He commanded that Zelophehad's daughters could marry only within their father's tribe.
36.q: What command did Yahweh give through Moses concerning Zelophehad's daughters?

36.a: No share of land in Israel can change from one tribe to another. Each man's share must stay within his ancestor's tribe.
36.q: What must never happen to shares of land in Israel?

36.a: Yahweh gave this command so that everyone among the people of Israel could own an inheritance from his ancestors.
36.q: Why did Yahweh command that every woman among the people of Israel who owned a share of land in her tribe must marry someone from the clans belonging to her father's tribe?

36.a: They married into the clans of the descendants of Manasseh so their inheritance remained in the tribe of their father's clan.
36.q: How did Zelophehad's daughters comply with this command from Yahweh?
